item.title: Painting a whole room with the world's blackest paint
item.description: A dramatic experiment transforms an entire room using ultra-black paint, showing how it absorbs light and changes depth perception in a way that looks almost unreal.

media:content.media:title: Painting a whole room with the world's blackest paint
media:content.media:description: A dramatic experiment transforms an entire room using ultra-black paint, showing how it absorbs light and changes depth perception in a way that looks almost unreal.

item.title: Sodium + Gasoline = I Got a Surprise
item.description: A controlled experiment combines sodium and gasoline, revealing an outcome that highlights the reactive properties of sodium and why careful handling is essential in chemistry.

item.title: The butterfly effect in real life
item.description: A science demonstration explores how tiny changes can lead to big outcomes, showing the real-world physics behind the butterfly effect and chaotic systems.

item.title: I melted wood with friction
item.description: A hands-on experiment shows how intense friction can generate enough heat to char and soften wood, breaking down the physics of energy transfer and temperature buildup.

item.title: Can you actually chew indium like gum?
item.description: An unusual experiment tests whether indium, a soft metal, can be chewed like gum, explaining its unique properties and what makes it behave so differently from most metals.

item.title: How close could you get to a neutron star?
item.description: A science breakdown explores what would happen as you approach a neutron star, explaining the extreme gravity, radiation, and forces that make it one of the most dangerous objects in the universe.

item.title: The world’s most dangerous greedy cup
item.description: A science demonstration tests a “greedy cup” that traps objects in unexpected ways, explaining the physics behind why it’s so difficult to escape once you’re caught.

item.title: Why no one can hear you scream in space
item.description: A science explanation breaks down how sound travels and why, without air, noise can’t move through space the way it does on Earth.

item.title: Can a fan blow things in a vacuum?
item.description: A simple experiment tests whether a fan can move objects without air, explaining what really happens in a vacuum and why air is essential for pushing things around.

item.title: Waving flag on the moon experiment
item.description: A science experiment recreates the Moon’s environment to test whether a flag can actually wave without air, explaining the physics behind one of the most common space myths.

item.title: The Dark Poisson's Spot
item.description: Poisson's Spot on The Darkest Ball In The World. Check how this is possible thanks to this experience.

item.title: I Trained a Ladybug To Follow My Pen
item.description: In this video I show you how a lady bug will follow a pen line and even avoid a permanent marker line. I talk about why it might be doing this odd behavior.

item.title: A thin slice of nothing
item.description: In this video I show you what it looks like when you have a thin slice of vacum next to a high density material like glass. I talk about thin film interference and the different ways that you can see it with different materials.

item.title: Seeing myself for the first time in a true mirror
item.description: A true mirror shows your reflection without left-right reversal, revealing how you actually look to others and why it feels so unfamiliar at first.

item.title: This ancient technology makes things spin really fast
item.description: A demonstration of an ancient device reveals how simple physics can create extremely fast spinning motion, showing that clever engineering existed long before modern machines.

item.title: Why you shouldn’t add ashes to sugar
item.description: A science experiment shows what happens when ashes are mixed with sugar, explaining the chemical reaction and why this combination leads to unexpected results.

item.title: This lens can make objects invisible
item.description: A science experiment shows how a special lens bends light in a way that hides objects from view, explaining the physics behind this invisibility effect.

item.title: Endless bouncing balls
item.description: A physics demonstration shows how bouncing balls can appear to keep moving endlessly, explaining the energy transfer and motion behind the effect.

item.title: Fried water
item.description: A surprising experiment shows how water can appear to be “fried,” breaking down the science and chemistry that make this counterintuitive result possible.

item.title: Can magnets actually make you cold?
item.description: An experiment explores how magnets interact with energy and motion, creating effects that can make objects feel colder than expected.
